comments.author: Emma
comments.content: This sounds awesome!  I don't have a spare $100 for the smoking gun, but I've had good luck with the MacGuyver-ed smoker from Dirt Candy.  The trick is lining the pot with foil first so nothing gets ruined.  I think I'll try this with the kimchee, which sounds awesome.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Indeed, a MacGuyvered smoking rig is totally fine; try not soaking the chips, and let them get fully hot before adding the food. I think you will love the flavor improvement.

comments.author: Moira
comments.content: Polyscience smoking gun ?  Oooohh ... I think there'd better be a better name for this!  And I'm not beyond using a camp torch to light a candle or some incense in a pinch ... but  I think I have to pass on this aparatus !  Like, Lucille Ball comes waltzing out of the kitchen to show Ethel her new "polyscience smoking gun".  You just know there's a disaster in the making! LoL.

comments.author: LInda
comments.content: Love just about anything smoked.  I have a small stove top smoker; going to give this a try very soon.  Also going to search for some fresh tofu (as I read your tips for preparing tofu) on a previous post.  Very informative.  Great blog!

comments.author: Naomi
comments.content: This recipe has me craving dim sum!!  I don't know where to get fresh tofu where I live, but I'm going to give it a try :)  Thanks for posting this!

comments.author: Culinary USA
comments.content: Now this looks like a fun recipe! Can't wait to try this for my next get together.

comments.author: Barbara Hartinger
comments.content: Hi, I live in a vegan household and would like to try to make the soft buns you refer to here. The Momofuku recipe I found on Food 52contains 3 tablespoons of nonfat dry milk powder. Do you have thoughts as to what a vegan replacement is for this? I'm not sure what its purpose is in the recipe. See this for discussion: https://www.livestrong.com/article/208885-vegan-substitutes-for-powdered-milk/

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hi Barbara - it's a good question; I've never tried replacing it so I don't have any reliable suggestions.
